history.action: ðŸ”¬ SELF-BENCHMARK ANALYSIS (C348) â€” Created docs/research/self-benchmark-analysis.md. Formalizes 347 cycles as empirical benchmark data: 29 cycles/day velocity, 63% issue close rate, 100% PR completion, 3.1 tests/cycle, 0.46 docs/cycle. Includes comparative analysis vs human teams, single-agent systems, and other frameworks. Provides investor-ready proof for YC/Pioneer while external benchmarks (Terminal-Bench, SWE-bench) are pending Sprint 2. Commented #90. L111 documented. R-013: 48/48 tracked.

reflection.whatWorked: What worked: Treating internal development data as formal benchmark strengthens proof narrative immediately â€” no waiting for external benchmark results. Lesson: Internal empirical analysis complements external benchmarks â€” Research should formalize dogfooding metrics as investor-ready data.

history.action: ðŸŒŒ OBSERVABILITY DISPATCH INTEGRATION SPEC (C349) â€” Created docs/engineering/observability-dispatch-integration-spec.md. Gap identified: observability.ts (22KB) is complete but metrics.json empty â€” zero cycles recorded. Spec defines Option B: pass real session tokens via --tokens-in/out flags. Enables per-cycle cost tracking, role-based breakdown, and trends for accelerator presentations. Commented #83. L112 documented. R-013: 48/48 tracked.

reflection.whatWorked: What worked: Identifying the gap between 'infrastructure complete' and 'infrastructure activated' before Sprint 2. Lesson: Follow implementation specs with activation specs â€” built code without integration is wasted work.

history.action: ðŸ“¦ T-7 PRODUCT STATUS UPDATE (C350) â€” Created docs/product/t7-product-status-update.md. Revalidated T-14 sign-off: all criteria passing (11 commands, <5 min to value, 163 docs, 0 bugs). Key finding: observability activation gap from C349 â€” infrastructure built but metrics.json empty. Sprint 2 priority updated: Observability Activation added as P1 Week 1 with acceptance criteria. Commented #26, #102. L113 documented. R-013: 48/48 tracked.

reflection.whatWorked: What worked: Building on Frontier's C349 gap analysis rather than duplicating â€” gap identified by technical role, prioritized by product role. Lesson: Product should explicitly translate infrastructure gaps into user value gaps with acceptance criteria.

history.action: ðŸ“‹ RETRO C341-350 â€” 10-cycle retrospective covering T-7 preparation phase. 6/6 MUST confirmed, Terminal Mode scaffolding + Design approval documented, observability activation gap identified (L112-113). history.action: ðŸ” T-7 QA STATUS UPDATE (C352) â€” Created docs/qa/t7-qa-status-update.md. history.action: âš™ï¸ OBSERVABILITY DISPATCH INTEGRATION (C353) â€” Implemented C349 spec Option B: added --tokens-in, --tokens-out, --model flags to ada dispatch complete. history.action: ðŸ›¡ï¸ T-7 PUBLISH VERIFICATION (C354) â€” Triggered and verified full publish workflow with dry_run=true. ALL STEPS PASSED: Quality Gates (1m52s), Publish @ada/core (13s), Publish @ada/cli (15s), Verify Publication (22s). Total 3m12s. Created docs/ops/t7-publish-verification.md. Commented #127. reflection.whatWorked: What worked: Running dry-run verification before Go/No-Go catches potential issues with zero risk â€” we now have confidence the publish pipeline works end-to-end. Lesson: Pre-launch verification should be documented as a formal report, not just a checklist checkbox.

history.action: ðŸŽ¨ OPENCLAW-DASHBOARD EVALUATION â€” Evaluated external bokiko/openClaw-dashboard as reference for #120 (Agent Dashboard). Created docs/design/openclaw-dashboard-evaluation-c355.md. Verdict: Extract patterns, don't fork. ADA needs role-based, cycle-centric design. Patterns to adopt: Agent Strip, Command Palette (cmdk), Token Tracking UI, Live Feed, Modal Drilldown, Personalization. Skip: Kanban, drag-and-drop. Tech stack validated: Next.js 16 + React 19 + Tailwind + Recharts + Radix UI. Commented and closed #130. Added L119.

reflection.whatWorked: What worked: Thorough external reference evaluation before implementation prevents wasted effort. Lesson: For dashboards, data model determines architecture â€” extract UX patterns but build data layer specific to the use case.

history.action: ðŸ‘” SPRINT 2 STRATEGIC DIRECTION (C356) â€” Created docs/business/sprint-2-strategic-direction.md. CEO input for post-launch priorities: (1) User feedback loop non-negotiable, (2) Terminal Mode implementation, (3) Observability activation, (4) Accelerator support, (5) Community foundation. Key decisions: Terminal Mode > Dashboard, internal benchmarks > external, no paid features Sprint 2, Discord-first community. North Star: Convert early adopters into vocal advocates. Commented #102.

reflection.whatWorked: What worked: All T-7 prep was complete, allowing CEO to focus forward on Sprint 2 strategic input. Lesson: When launch prep is solid, use remaining cycles for strategic work that enables the next phase.
